qas.question: What irradiates clouds of gas in the galaxy and makes them glow?
What can be detected via infrared prior to their emitting visible light?
What objects emit less of their energy as infrared light versus visible light?

plausible_answers.text: Cold, dark molecular clouds of gas and dust

qas.question: What glows with heat and shows visible light?
What can be used to detect protostars when they are cool?
What heats clouds of gas and makes them readily detected?
What do stars emit a smaller portion of in our galaxy?

context: The <b5_0>infrared portion of the spectrum<b5_0/> has several useful benefits for astronomers. <b3_0>Cold, dark molecular clouds of gas and dust<b3_0/> in our galaxy will glow with radiated heat as they are irradiated by <a0_0><b6_0>imbedded stars<b6_0/><a0_0/>. <b4_0>Infrared<b4_0/> can also be used to detect <a1_0>protostars<a1_0/> before they begin to emit visible light. <a2_0>Stars<a2_0/> emit a smaller portion of <b7_0>their energy<b7_0/> in the infrared spectrum, so nearby cool objects such as planets can be more readily detected. (In the visible light spectrum, the glare from the star will drown out the reflected light from a planet.)
